column8: View sensational! Insider tip for dizziness-free!
column11: A must have! Must see! But walk all the way up, not only the remains of the palace are worth seeing, but especially the view from the very top, where an old brick stupa still stands. But watch out for the numerous monkeys, they can get cheeky. The steps up to the palace are super steep and not for people who get dizzy quickly or who have trouble running, you really have to go up across, they are so narrow sometimes. Palace and stairs unique and the view priceless

column11: Hiking up Yapahuwa Rock Fortress was such a great experience! üèûÔ∏è The climb itself was enjoyable, not too difficult, but adventurous enough to make it exciting. The ancient stone steps and ruins along the way give a glimpse into Sri Lanka‚Äôs rich history, which made the hike even more special. column8: An out of the way treat
column11: An out of the way treat for the history and culture loving traveller. We made the mistake of going in the middle of the day when it was hot! The stairs are quite steep and not friendly to anyone with any sort of mobility issue (my wife and I only made it up the first two staircases) but all the locals visiting at the same time were incredibly friendly and one family even asked for a photo with my wife. A must see is the little Buddhist temple hidden around the corner from the entrance. Beautiful frescoes and such a cool tranquil feel to it.

A beautiful rock fortress on the way to Anuradhapura. 20 000LKR entry and we were the only tourists there (and somewhat a novelty for the locals who wanted photos taken with us). The steps are very steep but the walk up was worth it‚Ä¶ 360 view of the surrounding area. Highly recommend going off the beaten path to visit!
The view ist Amazing. You only need 30min on the top. Use normal shoes- no flipflop. On the entry you become a little bottle of water.
I had the mountain to myself! No one to see far and wide. The climb is exhausting, just because of the heat. But it's worth it. I would argue the smaller sigirya rock.
Very nice view . At the beginning steep stairs but feasible . Put on good shoes. Lots of monkeys on site . Few tourists

column8: Tourists coming to Sri Lanka can name it as a must visit kingdom.
column11: Yapahuwa is a kingdom of great historical value ruled by several kings. The kingdom of Yapahuwa, which has rarely caught the eye of foreign tourists, consists of a staircase that is more than 30 meters high made of very special stone carvings and stone pillars. When you climb the stairs to the top of the hill, you can see the ruins of the royal palace.

column8: Wonderful deserted rock fortress, with beautiful carved stairs, and a panoramic view.
column11: A great alternative to crowded Sigiriya, as no-one else was there in the morning.   My sister and I climbed to the top of this historic fortress, where the Tooth spent a few years in the 13th. century, and is in the centre of extensive ancient temple ruins.  Panoramic views from the flat top.

The Fortress is spectacular. We enjoyed the climb which had steep steps up-to a point. There is also a side path which is easier but then you would miss climbing the ancient steps . At 3.30 pm it was shady and made it easier. The cave temple also has 800 year old paintings. The surrounding garden also has wall relics to see.
Yapahuwa is a Sri Lankan Kingdom with a Rock Fortress consist with magnificiant Roch carvings / architecture. It locates in Kurunegala District. It is a must visit place in Sri Lanka.

Not as spectacular as Sigiriya but far less crowded and relaxed. Go early to avoid the heat of the day and take it easy to let it all sink in. The steps aren't as bad as we had been led to believe and although quite steep there are handholds and even a handrail part of the way on the second flight.
A really nice historical site. Not at all crowded and very atmospheric Lovely views from the top of the rock Highly recommended

Ok did the Yapahuwa rock fortress today it‚Äôs amazing not as good as lion rock on top but better in the climb no one was here had the hole place to ourselves the stairs are hard but the view is better than the over
Great Sunday morning walk - to the top. Also check out the cave temple at the bottom. Some beautiful early rock paintings and old statues. Those by the entrance are modern.
Yapahuwa: Over our expectations! Ancient site with a more than perfect view, combined with a short exercise
Pn the left of the stairs is a walking path that takes you. Sorry but cannot get excited about this place..

Amazing rock fortress. Build in 13th century. We had 2 hour journey from kandy. There are 3 sets of stairways. The 2nd one is really hard to climb. Both side of the 3rd steps has great sculptures and many rock carvings. After that there is a impressive rock doorway to the temple of tooth. After this we climbed to the rock which is bit hard. But the top was amazed. There is a stupa on the top of the rock. There is a cave temple also at the bottom of the rock fortres.
That is a most beautiful rock fortress in sri lanka.that called little sigiriya.there are lot of ancient ruins and also most beautiful place arround you.

This is a great historical place with many ancient ruins remain. If you love historical places and ancient cities this is a good place to visit. You can see remaining parts of stone palace. This is amazing. On top of the rock you can see nice view of the area.
We explored this amazing place and walked up to the top, the last bit is not for the faint hearted as you will need to use the ropes provided
This place of buddhist worship is a must for Tourists interested in the ancient history of Sri lanka.  Many narrow steps to climb, no footwear and modest dress. A lot to see

We took the approximately 2 hour bus from Kurunegala to Maho for maybe 100LKR. Then we paid 300 for a tuktuk to the site. The entry was approximately 700. The hike to the top was well worth it with amazing views and although it was hot it took less than 1/2 hour to the top. We had the top all to ourselves although on our way down a group of maybe 100 school children was headed up. We didn't have a guide and I didn't read the signboards that were in English and there was also a tiny museum. But a beautiful site.

Make sure you visit in the cooler months or early in the morning as you need an hour at least if you are climbing to the summit.  Climbing in mid day heat is not the best.  Also need to be careful when climbing as part of the steep way up is via close steps with no hand rails

A lovely introduction to historical Sri Lanka and hardly any western tourists (although plenty of local ones). We only went up half-way as that‚Äôs where most of the ruins are.

We met one Sri Lankan man, but otherwise it was just us. We climbed up three flights of steps, one flight with great stone carvings. This earned us good views. We then scrambled over rocks to the top which was a bit harder, but really worth the effort.

This is one of the ancient kingdom in Sri Lanka. It has a great rock fortress which is so much scenery. After that you can walk until top of the mountain. It was a sunny day when we travel but we didn't feel the sun a bit after reaching to the top because of the wind which is so much cold. It's worth traveling to this place.
Yapahuwa is the 4th capital in Sri Lanka. this rocky fortress and stone carvings amazing, hundreds of steps with over 75 degrees of angle

In Yapahuwa Stone rock at the top of the stairs there is a large stone door way, flanked by big walls and two exquisitely carved windows. One window was found in fragments but the other, called the ‚ÄòSivumenduru Kavuluwa‚Äô is well preserved at the National Museum in Colombo.
The magnificent Yapahuwa Rock is iconic among all archaeological sites in Sri Lanka for the sheer mastery in rock carving.

Capital of Sri Lanka for about 10 years at the end of the 13th century, Yapahuwa was a palace and a fortress built on a 90 meter tall boulder, hence a lot of steps and climbing to be done nowadays to see the remains of its past glory. Not much is left: a few caves at the bottom with Buddhist frescoes and statues, a most impressive stone staircase, with lions and apsaras carved on the sides and the remains of the stupa on the top, which also offers nice views of the surrounding area. It was mid afternoon when we visited and, with the exception of a monk at the entrance of the premises, there was nobody else, weather was good, it was quiet - which all added to mystery and the beauty of the place...

Yapahuwa is one the most ancient cities in SRI LANKA -it was a capital in the late 12th century. The fortress was built on a 100 meter high granite block, and the ruins are worth of climbing of the steep slopes.  Its' importance is proved by the big number of student-groups - seems this is an important element of the history.  And you can hardly see tourists there!!

Located about 135 km from Colombo.A tooth temple of one of Sri Lanka's ancient capitals. During a period of political instability, King Bhuvanekabahu 1 moved his capital to Yapahuwa in 1272 CE ,taking with him the sacred Tooth Relic. After his death, the fortress was eventually abandoned.
We visited Yapahuwa on the road from Arunadhapura to the airport. A great walk in the jungle (very hot: humid), beautiful views and a nice temple. No foreign tourists but us when we were there.

Very scenic routes after Wariyapola town. Without much rush you can paddle 80 kms a day. We reached Maho town just 8s from the Yapahuwa Rock Fortress and the following day climbed the rock. It‚Äôs a moderate climb and even young kids can do it.

It will not take 2-3 hrs to reach summit but the view from top is totally worth it. It‚Äôs windy out there Make sure to dress properly as you are entering to the temple area.  And try to avoid walking or sitting in the ruins of the fortress Not hard to climb. Worth visiting

We were happy that we made the effort to hike up to the top of Yapahuwa Rock Fortress. The steep staircase is a bit daunting at first glance but its not hard to climb. The carvings are about a third of the way up and you could turn around at this point if you aren't keen on scrambling up to the summit. We continued on and reached the summit in about 15 minutes. Nice views of the surrounding countryside from the top, but it was very windy. Ticket price was weird, for 3 adults we paid Rs 1910, which is about Rs 636 each. There are toilet facilities in the parking lot area.
this is the best place that you can see the talents of ancient sri lanka stone works and recommended if you visit sri lanka to see this place

When we arrived at Yapahuwa the rain started but we carried on with umbrellas. It is a short walk to the start of the climb. The rock stairs are shallow and uneven so proceed with caution. Especially in the rain! Two of us didn‚Äôt make it to the top but we did make it far enough to take in the beautiful view. We sat for a while and tried to imagine carving all those stone stairs and the wonderful lion. Just amazing. The one of us who did make it close to the top said the views just got better and better.

Yapahuwa was the capital of ancient Sri Lanka sometime between 1272-1284 AD. It was then captured by a South Indian army and later destroyed by the Portuguese. The magnificent stone stairway is steep and leads to a small plateau where the palace once stood. On either side of the third tier of stairs are rock carvings. Among them are the only Chinese-style Lions to be seen in Sri Lanka. Further rock steps lead to the top of the mountain where an ancient stupa, natural rock pond and the ruins of a building are still visible. The views from the 100 metre high rock are wonderful. Take care when climbing and descending because the steps are narrow and uneven.

My wife and I visited Yapahuwa on 5th January 2018, to see this ephemeral city that was the capital of Sri Lanka for a mere 12 years.  Today, Yapahuwa is a unique location of historic splendour, with its majestic rock carvings on either side of the stone stairway leading to what was the pavilion where the sacred tooth relic was kept.  I wore good walking shoes and carried a sun-hat.  We visited the site early morning to avoid the noon time heat and humidity.  There is no entry fee for locals and residents while the foreigners are charged a 4 USD (Rs. 620) fee. King Buwanekabahu who inherited the kingdom in 1272AD established his capital at Yapahuwa and built this rock fortress not only to defend the Sinhalese kingdom from the Indian Army garrisoned at Polonnaruwa but also for his own safety.  He also moved the Buddha‚Äôs sacred tooth relic and installed it in a building at the top of the rock to safeguard it from the enemy, for it was the belief that whoever had the tooth relic was the King.  However, after Buwanekabahu‚Äôs untimely demise in 1284, South Indians captured Yapahuwa and took away the tooth relic to India.  Thereafter Yapahuwa was largely abandoned but for some ascetic Buddhist monks.  To complete the history, the tooth relic was recovered later by his successor after negotiations with the Indian King and brought back to Sri Lanka. We entered the protected compound through the south gate after passing the ticket counter.  We went past the moat and a tall outer wall embankment in semi-circular pattern about 11 km long that encircled and safeguarded the city.  At the end of the semicircle is the steep Yapahuwa rock itself.  As I entered through the wide embankment of the fortress, I could not help being fascinated by the 100 metre tall rock that looms and abruptly rises above the surrounding plains.  We walked along neatly kept grounds for about 150 metres to the inner wall within which was the king‚Äôs palace and what would have been his council rooms for the war cabinet. The highlight of the visit was the sprawling, majestic and imposing stairway leading to the sanctum of the sacred tooth.  There are three flights of stairs.  The damaged lowest stairway had been restored with concrete steps while the upper two stairways are the originals, built of stone.  The first two staircases take you to a pavements of flat areas supported by retaining walls built of stone slabs.  The second staircase is not only steep at about 70 degrees but also narrow making you place your feet sideways - presumably to make it difficult for the enemy to get a foothold on during an attack.  Looking down from here I took a few photographs of the ruins of King Buwanekabahu‚Äôs palace, quite close to the bottom of the first staircase. The third stairway is awe inspiring in its beauty and breath-taking to look at.  The steps are wider too. Unlike the other two staircases both sides of this one are ornately carved with various figures ‚Äì young girls holding a pot to welcome you, the head and trunk of elephant and the famed Yapahuwa Lion which appeared in one of the currency notes.  The sculpture displayed in these figures are amazing and spectacular. Crossing the doorway at the top of the staircase you enter the top plateau which again is supported by a retaining wall built of stone slabs.  Here I gazed at the ruins of the pavilion of the sacred tooth.  The columns in the doorway too are magnificently decorated.  The view of the surroundings from here, from so high up, is breath-taking, miles and miles of forest and fields in all directions! Turn left and follow the path to the top of the rock.  I went only half-way and did not attempt to climb this as it was far too steep for me.  On the way back we visited the adjoining temple too dating back to the 13th century and situated just outside the innermost wall of the city. It was a tiring climb but very informative, awe inspiring and educative.

The ruins of the first imperial palace where the Budha tooth was kept is fascinating for its moats, carvings, staircase and caves. The lions at the head of the stairs are figured on the 10 Rupee note.

Located in Kurunegala District, North Western Province. Approximate height  around 90M. Approximately 112Km from Banadaranayake international airport.  This suppose to be royal residence in 13th centaury. This was build by king Buwanekabahu and happen to be capital of Sri Lanka in 1301 This is surrounded by stone wall height approximately 12 mtrs and around 500 yards. Up of the rock you can experience caves as well

This is more of off the beaten track! We chose this since as a stopover place to visit after arriving in SL and reaching Polonnaruwa by night. Very scenic and beautiful, this place entices you to climb higher and higher and then at the end of it (the arduous climb!) yo are rewarded with awesome landscape. Not a very touristy place still (thank God!) Better to visit to the little museum first!
Situate in North western province of Sri lanka surrounded by coconuts and paddy cultivation it,s about 110km from international Air Port

Challenging climb to the top of this daunting rock face. View the scenic landscape. Experience the ruins of a 1200 year old temple. Imagine the rich history of the area. Cooling temperatures as you ascend the windswept well maintained trail to the top. Breathtaking!

Have to walk and climb a series of steps to catch and hold the beauty of the place. The fortress is built of stone, making us suprised of the talent of ancient people and excellent architects lived in that era. At the top of rock, there are monuments of old temple.Through out the journey you can have eye grasping view while having a rest. Not much crowded.The place is well kept and clean compared to other historical places in Sri Lanka. Don't forget to go to museum if you love knowing the facts about the place.The is a book stall too.

It would help to visit the small museum and listen to the guide about the Yapahuwa Kingdom prior to the climb. The first sector is ascending the stone stairs shown in the profile photo for this site and then a steep climb to the Sigiriya-like rock. Even a few elderly ladies in our group managed to climb it with some effort. Took about an hour.

The fortress is a fully pleaded ancient kingdom similar to Sigiriya although the maintenance is not being done to extract the best. You have to climb about 250 steps in a steeper one off way and then 250 more rocky steps to reach the top, which is pretty tiresome. But the view from the top can compensate for the effort.

Yapahuwa is a 13th century rock fortress that rises about 300 feet abruptly from the plain.  It was the capital of Sri Lanka for just 12 years, from 1272 to 1284.  A climb to the top is highly recommended, although dawn or dusk are the best times unless you choose a cloudy day.  The sun during the day can be fiercely hot.  You will see interesting statues, rock carvings and frescoes.  There is also a lovely temple.

We visited this place during a six hours drive from Colombo to the North. Unfortunately only the groud walls of this fortress can still be seen besides a beautiful portal that you can reach after climbing around 60 steps. The view on top of the hill is amazing and definitely worth a visit when you are in this area.

This place isn't very easy to find or wasn't for us anyway. When we got there wow. Just the walk up through the gardens to the rock learning about the moats then the steps started it's a hard climb and a few daunting walkways that look like they are only held on by a couple of struts I think people with vertigo or a fear of heights should stay away good day
Many steps were there to be walked to the rock top. The greenery was nice and the view from the above was stunning. Not a crowded place.

Lovely and 'wild' - we were the only tourists there. It's quite a hike but magnificent views and everyone local that we met was very friendly. It's quite amazing to have the dense bush, ancient ruins and majestic rock all together.

Yapahuwa. is' really interesting and a good walk up the many steps to the top of the rock. The climb to the top through the trees with few steps was not anticipated but great.  There are very steep steps which could be very dangerous.  Entry fee is also steep at 1000 rupee per person.
Be prepared for good climbing but it definetely worths the effort. Beautiful ruins with lions and dragons figures
Glad  I went here. Ruins are greatly restored.  Everywhere is green and refreshing. View on the top is amazing

This is 3rd Kingdom of Sri Lanka and still alive with it's proudness . The long stairway is magnificent and bit danger since small space for foot.Amazing panoramic view at top. Comparing to other places this is almost empty.The cave image house at temple is worth a visit. Place is much relaxing and peaceful. Important : This is a temple now ,keep silent and behave well.

Yapahuwa is the third kingdom in Sri Lanka. It is easily accessible from train or a taxi. Make sure you climb up the mountain and get panoramic views of the surrounding. Take a photo with the Lion statue on the way up, which is kind of a icon in Sri Lanka. Always less crowded than Sigiriya.

This long stairway is magnificent, the most beautiful I saw in Sri Lanka. There is a little painted Buddhist cave as well at the base of the rock that worth to be seen. We visited at early morning (9am) and there was almost nobody, excepted few locals.

Once the capital of ancient Sri Lanka, albeit briefly, Yapahuwa is definitely worth a visit. The ruins are not as well preserved as other sites in Sri Lanka, but what is left is now protected. The climb to the top is steep and strenuous, but the views from the top are well worth the climb.

This rock fortress seems off the beaten path but its really interesting. Much smaller then Sigiriya. Some ruins around bottom of stairs. Stairs are steep, be careful. Lots of monkeys running around too. The old temple of the tooth ruins are found at the top. Great views from the top. I recommend visiting if in the area.
Unlike Sigiriya, this palace was built at the foot of the rock, protected by a moats and semi-circular walls.  The stone staircase is impressive and visiting the museum is worthwhile.

Hundreds of steps actually, which each landing area proving a panoramic view of the surrounding country side. The steps are a bit uneven and steep but with a series of good landing areas. A quarter way up you get two see the two lions which form the backdrop to one of the local currency notes. The steps and some sections of the perimeter walls are all that remain of this citadel and third capital city but I sort of liked it - even though I did not go as far as the summit. Nice place for a brief stop on the road from Anuradhapura to Colombo!

Yapahuwa Rock Fortress is a huge rock outcrop rising from the dry plains of north western Sri Lanka.This was the seat of governance and the shrine of the sacred tooth relic of Buddha in the 13th century.The place is best known for its number of rock carvings, the most notable being a chinese styled lion carved out of solid rock.  The access to the top of the rock begins with a flight of steps which are approximately at an angle of 70 degrees! The path to the top of the 400 ft high rock begins here. The climb starts gradual and the gradient increases as it reaches the top. The climb is a tiring exercise but the stunning view of surrounding countryside will make you soon forget it.You won't find a lot of people there. There were ruins of many an ancient building, some of which could be identified as Stupas.Once you climb down from the rock on your way back, you must visit the museum  which contains many valuable artifacts, which are on permanent display. This is one of the few places admire the fine, artistic skills of the ancient stone craftsmen.

It doesn't matter if you are a nature lover, hiker, historical place explorer, sight seeker, yapahuwa is ideal place for all of them. Yapahuwa is a relic mountain situated about 40 km away from kurunegala town and is onthe way to Anuradhapura via kurunegala, as it consist of a steep slope you need to have much effort to climb up the rock, once you clime up the rock the view is amazing .

If you want to visit a historical place in Sri Lanka and don't have much time to spend, this place should be one of them if you are heading towards Anuradhapura. It is only 9 Km deviation from Daladagama  Junction. I am sad that I did not discover this place prior to 15th July as I have passed this way many a times. The place is amazing and the view from the top is breath taking. Let me warn you that the initial steps are the very steep. I was told the peak is about 300ft from the ground level. It is a marvel to think back and ponder how an ancient King decided to make use of this mammoth Rock. Best time to climb would be early morning as it can get really hot. Please be careful when you are descending and don't forget to hold on to the hand rail (bit rusty) Highly recommended attraction to people who are not afraid of height's and not for once who need special care or on wheel chairs.
Very interesting but the steps are very steep and the handrain is low.  It is a long climb to the top but worth it.

Sometimes referred to as The Citadel, this takes some getting to but is worth the trip. Climbing up to it requires some effort (particularly in the constant heat and humidity) and many of the steps are quite narrow or cut into rock.  This is not for the traveller afraid of heights, nor the one with mobility difficulties, but if you can manage it you will be rewarded with the most amazing views of the total area.  The features about one third of the way up are really quite impressive and the view from here is pretty good, so if you can't manage the rest just do the first set of quite steep stairs up to the main landing.  There isn't much to see at the top in terms of historical interest, but as mentioned, the view is extraordinary.

This is certainly an off the beaten track attraction. It's a dramatic stairway that takes you up to the ruins of a palace. The very steep climb is certainly worth it. You get rewarded with a magnificent wide view of the beautiful landscape and of course the platform and stairway in itself are beautiful too. As not many people go here you can take lots of great pictures. Don't skip this attraction, but don't tell everyone as that would spoil the beauty of this wonderful place.

Yapahuwa offers incredible views over surrounding countryside, with an ascent that's quite demanding (particularly when it's hot). There were only a few people around when I visited at c.10am, and the area is very rural. It is definitely well worth a visit. The climb is steep, and there are handrails in only a few places so you must be careful. After the first three staircases, there is a path to follow up to the top of the fortress. Make sure to take plenty of water and something to give you shade from the sun. There's a Buddhist shrine and a small museum to visit near the base (plus sitting-style toilets). Watch out for monkeys!

Amazing ancient fortess with beautiful staircase leading to the palace in ruins. A nice rock climb and beautiful view of the surroundings at the top. Make sure to check out the amazing view and the stupa at the top.

Visited the Rock Fortress several times and still thinking go back again. The panoramic view at the top of the fortress is unforgettable and the mild wind makes feel very comfortable after a bit tired climbing to the top. The Climbing steps are bit over angled at the beginning but once you start its all right. Be careful on your steps when you descending at the last phase of rock steps. For my age its interesting . Select a morning or evening to visit the place , then you will be bit comfort with the hot climate in area. Carry a small bag / back pack with a small water bottle, and few snacks and do not forget your camera, shades and a cap/hat.  Pls do not let any litter there and its a very clean and restricted zone for plastic and polythene. Now the roads are ok and hope its a must see place for all srilnkans and all visitors to Sri Lanka, specially who visit Anuradhapura.

Visited several times with my family and friends...though it feel hard to climb the rock....u can feel much better once climbed to the top. the surrounding environment with full of ancient ruins of a palace..feel proud as a local traveler... Can reach from train to maho and another few KM way from the town..local bus service too available. Highly recommend to any type of visitors...

I had no expectations of this attraction so I was delighted with the experience. Its a stiff climb up to the caves so you need to be reasonably fit. But well worthwhile - the views are stunning, the monkeys fun and the mixture of landscape from the rock faces to the jungle paths makes it a rewarding experience. Not as crowded as some of the other religious sites we visited.

Wonderful, old rock fortress, definitely a must-visit in my view.  I really felt like I have stepped back in time to the ancient kingdom when I climbed the steep steps in to the hall. Beautiful lion scultures an columns. The climb to the top through the trees with few steps was not anticipated but great. The view from the top was amazing. And best of all there were hardly other people at the top with us, one of my favourite historical places in Sri Lanka for sure.

We got off at the train at Maho and got a three wheeler the 6 ks to Yapahuwa. Its' really interesting and a good walk up the many steps to the top of the rock but like many places, the entry fee just keeps rising - currently 1000rupee and that makes it unattractive to make the effort to see it as there is nothing else of interest close by. Once again you have the place pretty much to yourself, especially if you climb all the way to the top (like Sigirya). The views are marvellous but the ruins are just that and there is no where that I could find any information about the sight. The vihaya next door has a nice little cave temple (at no cost) so make sure that you don't miss that.

Little remains here.The three stage staircase leads up to a platform where once stood the temple for the tooth relic.  Carvings include dancing girls, drummers and other performers.  Statues on the staircases include lions and elephants.  There are many macaque monkeys flitting about.

The key attraction is the ornately decorated staircase. steep, tall and narrow steps. I found the rock paintings in the temple at the foot of the rock to be impressive as well. The climb to the top is mildly strenuous. Advise to start early in the day as it gets to be pretty hot with the afternoon sun. Its like being in an open oven once the rock gets heated up. Taking a bottle of water is definitely advisable. The climb took us less than an hour at a leisurely pace, with photo stops. The view from the top is beautiful. Plenty of parking is available by the archaeological museum. There is a pathway from the museum to the  site of the fortress, over the now dried out moat and across the ruins of the fortress rampart. Whats visible now are the buildings and structures part reconstructed by the archaeological department. On the staircase, towards the upper left, there is an opening on the outside wall, which is an inspection passage/tunnel made by the archaeological department. Many try to explain this as a secret tunnel made by the king as an emergency exit route. A very romantic notion. It actually does have the appearance of a secret passageway as it is very well concealed.

very hard work to do. but so beautiful, very nice for trekking. This is a kingdom in sri lanka. can walk around the citadel area by seeing the ruins of the buildings. Entrance to the mountain is so beautiful. nicely carved on granite. when going to the top of the mountain some places hard steps to go, but good. top of the mountain have ruins of a stupa. quite good place to visit.

This is an amazing place to visit. it's a well worth visit for anyone who is planning to visit Dambulla. Yapahuwa is situated between Kurunagala and Dambulla in the North-Western province of Sri Lanka.  It is advisable to visit the museum first to get an overall understanding of the fortress and its history. The details carved on a hard granite surface is unbelievable. The similarity between  some of the carvings including the famous Yapahuwa Lion, and the carvings found in the ancient  East Asia, shows a close link between Sri Lanka and East Asia during that time. Though the steps are carved, the climb is steep. The steps are narrow making it compulsory for the climber to climb sideways. Nearby is a cave where the monks used to meditate. Notice the techniques used by them to prevent water coming in during the rainy season

It is not one of the Ancient Cities attractions but it is worth to visit. It is on the way from Colombo to Anuradhapura so is not a great deviation. It is a solid monolithic rock of a little more of 100 meters tall covered by nice vegetation, sometimes like a small jungle. At the middle of the climbing there are the rest of what was to be a fortress which are very nice and you can take good picture. You climb thru stairs made of stone not difficult but the steps are higher than normal. From there there are no more stairs and you have to climb by you own means. Yapahuwa is in the Kurunegala District and off the beaten track. However, it is well worth the visit. Such a tranquil area. Read the history about the place and be informed before you visit. A tour guide who was there said that it was one of the places where the Buddha's Tooth Relic was enshrined and the steps to the summit were made tall and narrow to prevent anyone for stealing it and running away with it. At least one person dies from falling down the stairs each year, so take great care when descending. The last bit does not have steps and one has to use the trees to hold on to the the roots have made the steps.
